text: [Music]
I actually do think the African-American
churches have more to to
lose than we white churches do now if
you go into Redeemer you're going to
find that redeemer is about
Anglo about 45% Asian and about 10% %
Black and Hispanic uh a lot of the
churches in the middle or uh in the
middle or lower
Manhattan that are more um Evangelical
Orthodox charismatic will have that same
kind of mixture there's very few white
churches
around um I'd say the ethnic churches
which would be the African-American
churches the Latino churches the Asian
churches uh it it is more difficult for
them to become multi-ethnic because in
some ways they they're community centers
for their people and they lose some of
the uh their some of some of their power
in a sense as representing their people
to the broader culture it could be that
in uh Post Obama there's big questions
about the old models for how you do
ethnic
empowerment and I but that's not
something for me to speak to I don't
think I mean I actually counsel all
churches you I say you should be as
multi-ethnic or more multi-ethnic than
your neighborhood so if you live in a
neighborhood that is so many
African-Americans so many black uh
Latinos so many white you should try
your church should look like your
neighborhood and if you are you actually
do better than the neighborhood because
usually out in the neighborhood those
groups of people don't mix all that well
they're usually alongside of each other
maybe friendly but they don't really
work together so if you could be a
church that shows how the groups work
together you could in a sense be more
multiethnic than your neighborhood but
basically we say be as multi-ethnic as
your geog graphy so I push that pretty
pretty heavily and so yeah I would love
to see uh a multi-ethnic future church
but I realize the ethnic churches have a
lot to lose so I'm careful when I say
that I don't want to make them feel that
somehow they're doing wrong to stay more
monoth I still see a role for that I
don't I don't see much of a role for a
purely white church anymore but I do see
a role for the ethnic
churches uh when I got here in the 80s
in the late 80s nobody thought that that
was the case again that's one of the
ways in which New York City has been a
big a very big help to me not so much my
theological training I got here and
recognized the potential of cities I
think and began to say churches have got
to become more pro-urban
because because the culture is getting
more pro-urban and it really is the
negativity of of Americans toward the
cities has really turned around we don't
quite know why some people said it was
friends in
Seinfeld that in the in the early 90s
you had these great sitcoms that showed
people in cities being very attractive
and I don't know what it is but I sense
the change in the early 90s that
suddenly there was a change in the
culture so I say to churches be
pro-urban don't be anti-urban because uh
the trend at least for the next 50 years
is going to be very pro-urban
